reviews.text: The best thing about this hotel is the location and the fact that you can pre-book connecting rooms without waiting until you get there to see if they have allocated you one (I have very rarely come across any other hotels that do this!). The rate is currently $117 for double room or $234 for set of connecting rooms on their website. This is great value for Singapore. The rooms are fairly small (similar size to Traders) as are the bathrooms, but clean enough for a 3 star hotel, it doesnt pretend to be 5 star. We had 3 adults and 2 kids in 2 rooms.Ours also had a fridge, safe, tv hairdryer, internet etc. Its a 5 minute walk to Clarke Quay, with lots of pubs, clubs and restaurants, great for a daytime or evening stroll. They have even developed Robertson Quay itself into a mini Clarke Quay with bars and restaurants on your doorstep. The hotel also has its own bar with deck chairs next to the river and a daily happy hour. Breakfast was basic compared to big hotels, but had coffee, tea, juice, cereals, sausages, beans and eggs, plenty for us and tasted good. Has a small pool with slide going in it, adequate for kids and adults to cool off in.
reviews.title: Good value for Singapore & great location, with pre-bookable connecting rooms!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: 2 nights in what I thought was a 3 star hotel. I suggest you do not go by pictures in website or brochures, rather shabby and worn out hotel in desperate need of a clean, modernisation and general revamp. Great rates offered considering it has ok size outside pool but no excuse for general dirty state. Bed was small but compfy but we were not completely relaxed due to linen having worn out discoloured old look/feel plus the headboard was really obviously dirty. Bathroom was disgusting and tiny, they could at least attempt to get rid of the black mould from tiles and shower curtain. Breakfast below average, would rather they quote room only rates and charge for breakfast, they'd soon have to improve it ! Location was good, in front of quiet, prity river location, short walk to some nice bars, cafe's and restaurants. Would not recommend, would suggest pay bit extra.
reviews.title: dissapointed

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I had the misfortune to stay 3 nights at this hotel. We arrived after an overnight flight and the last thing we wanted was to check into a damp & dirty room with bloodstained sheets. Having requested to move to a better room we eventually were, but the second room was equally as bad. Pointing this out to the reception staff we were informed all rooms were of the same standard!! Eventually, after 3 hours of constant discussion with the reception staff, we were moved again. Admitedly the cleaner seemed to have managed to at least find some sheets without blood stains this time but the room was still not cleaned to a moderate standard. This is a very poor hotel relying on people booking via a website who have never stayed there before. Don't fall into the same trap! And I'm not some fussy traveller accustomed to 5 star luxury. Having backpacked through China, Central Asia & Iran for a year I know how many places out there appreciate your custom and make an effort to provide a good level of service. Don't give your money to the few who think there's a cheap $ to be made out of visitors !!
reviews.title: Dirty hotel & room - avoid this place !!
Small room but good deal
reviews.text: The Robertson Quay Hotel is a gem in the rough. Unless your idea of a hotel room is somewhere you can sit in an easy chair or sofa while you put your feet up on the coffee table, This place is the place to stay. You couldn't pick a better location in Singapore. It is right on the esplanade along the Singapore River and only a 5 minute walk from the MTR station. It is half the price of other hotels in the same area, and with good reason ... the rooms are very small and basic.

Think stateroom, not hotel room. The guy I was traveling with was a fellow retired naval officer. Both of us remarked how much the room reminded us of our staterooms on Navy ships. They had everything you needed and nothing extra. The room was small, the beds were comfortable and the bathroom was "compact" but held all the necessities. (don't think free shower caps and hand lotion ... I mean toilet, sink, and shower) There was a TV, a telephone, and internet access. What else do you need?
